body_html:
I was very happy to finally be able to build tensorflow from source, but when running it for the first time, I was hitting issue #121. "ImportError: undefined symbol: clock_gettime #121".

This seems to be a never ending story.

First I had a problem with "ulimit -u" for installing bazel, which is required for building tensorflow. On many systems it is set to 256 by default, which is not enough to build bazel.

Then I hit a problem with specifying a proxy server, such that tensorflow can download some dependencies (tensorflow fails to use a proxy server, when the hostname ends with a "/". The solution is to remove the slash)

Then I had the problem with tensorflow not recognizing Python in a non-standard location, which was solved by checking out release 0.9 from github.

Then I hit the problem with the non-existing "external" directory, solved by downloading release 0.3.0 of bazel

Then I had to fight with pip that it does not destroy my Python 3.3.3 installation.

And finally I get runtime errors.

It be nice if the "troubleshooting" paragraph at the bottom of the instructions for building tensorflow from source could be extended, such that other users do not need experience the above-mentioned problems themselves, especially since some of them are known issues.

body:
I was very happy to finally be able to build tensorflow from source, but when running it for the first time, I was hitting issue #121. "ImportError: undefined symbol: clock_gettime #121".

This seems to be a never ending story.

First I had a problem with "ulimit -u" for installing bazel, which is required for building tensorflow. On many systems it is set to 256 by default, which is not enough to build bazel.

Then I hit a problem with specifying a proxy server, such that tensorflow can download some dependencies (tensorflow fails to use a proxy server, when the hostname ends with a "/". The solution is to remove the slash)

Then I had the problem with tensorflow not recognizing Python in a non-standard location, which was solved by checking out release 0.9 from github.

Then I hit the problem with the non-existing "external" directory, solved by downloading release 0.3.0 of bazel

Then I had to fight with pip that it does not destroy my Python 3.3.3 installation.

And finally I get runtime errors.

It be nice if the "troubleshooting" paragraph at the bottom of the instructions for building tensorflow from source could be extended, such that other users do not need experience the above-mentioned problems themselves, especially since some of them are known issues.
